21 D. ­ EUROPE DU NORD : LES MILLE ET UN VISAGES DE LA DÉCENTRALISATION A l'inverse du centralisme administré cher à l'Europe du Sud, c'est la décentralisation qui semble prévaloir dans l'Europe du Nord. Mais là encore, l'analyse plus poussée des systèmes conduit à remarquer des differences notables. Γ/ ­ Allemagne : le corset du fédéralisme. Il est fréquent d'entendre dire que le système éducatif allemand est totalement décentralisé, alors que la réalité fait apparaître au travers de la conception fédérale de l'Etat, une juxtaposition de pouvoirs régionaux centralisateurs. Ici ce sont les <r Lander » qui exercent en pleine souveraineté (ou presque) les compétences en matière d'éducation et de formation. Notons cependant qu'en matière de formation professionnelle par exemple, c'est le pouvoir fédéral qui réglemente pour l'ensemble des régions l'organisation de ce type de formation. Chaque * Land » allemand est en fait une manière d'Etat doté d'un Parlement et d'un ministre de l'Education qui fixe les programmes d'enseignement, arrête les structures pédagogiques ainsi que les modalités de recrutement et de formation des enseignants. La régulation par le pouvoir fédéral, intervient au travers d'instances spécifiques de planification (Commission de planification pour la construction d'établissements d'enseignement supérieur, ou Commission de la Fédération et des Länder pour la planification dans le domaine de l'éducation et la promotion de la recherche...). Par ailleurs, le besoin réel de coordination des politiques scolaires des Länder a conduit à la création de la Conférence permanente des Ministres de l'Education et des Affaires culturelles. Ainsi par le canal de conventions particulières établies entre les dix Länder de l'Allemagne de l'Ouest, ont été harmonisés certaines composantes des programmes scolaires, mais aussi les durées de l'obligation scolaire et des vacances scolaires, tout autant que la terminologie relative à l'organisation des structures éducatives, ou à l'évaluation des résultats. De la même façon des conventions spécifiques lient par exemple les Länder et les Universités ou les Ecoles Supérieures de Technologie. On le voit le pouvoir central dans cette forme de fédéralisme corseté n'a rien négligé pour préserver l'unité nationale et la cohérence des structures éducatives. Rappelons que les diplômes décernés dans chaque Land ont valeur * nationale » y compris ceux délivrés par les universités autonomes puisqu'une convention entre la Conférence permanente des Ministres de l'Education des Länder et la Conférence des Recteurs de l'Allemagne Fédérale porte tout à la fois sur les contenus et les modalités des examens d'Etat et des examens propres aux universités. Ici, c'est donc bien le concept de fédéralisme qui se substitue à celui de décentralisation. Chaque Land est ici maître du jeu éducatif même s'il est tenu par la Loi Fondamentale à circonscrire strictement ses pouvoirslègislatifs à l'espace et au champ d'initiative que lui confère la dévolution organique de souveraineté régionale. Au sein de chaque Land, « le Ministère de l'Education et des Affaires culturelles représente le niveau supérieur, l'autorité administrative intermédiaire du Land le niveau intermédiaire, et l'administration scolaire des villes et des communes le niveau inférieur ». On retrouverait presque dans ce dispositif, un cadre institutionnel qui caractérise ailleurs le centralisme administré. 2°/ ­ Belgique : le fédéralisme linguistique au fil de Peau. Si le fédéralisme allemand fortement corseté peut apparaître rassurant aux yeux d'un observateur cartésien quant à la cohérence obtenu du système éducatif, la plus grande perplexité pourrait sans doute s'emparer du même observateur confronté à la dernière version du fédéralisme belge ! En effet ici, en ce pays de dix millions d'habitants, le système fédéral repose sur l'existence de trois régions (Flandre, Wallonie, Bruxelles), de trois communautés, et de quatre régions Linguistiques (néerlandaise, française, allemande et franco­néerlandaise). Nous sommes bien au coeur d'un carrefour culturel et linguistique attachant où depuis de très longues années les collectivités territoriales jouent un rôle déterminant dans l'organisation des institutions éducatives. La loi constitutionnelle affirme ici une liberté totale d'initiative en matière d'éducation à partir d'un minimum d'impératifs. C'est dire combien les * Pouvoirs organisateurs » c'est­à­dire l'Etat, l'Eglise catholique, les provinces, les communes, mais aussi les autres confessions reconnues (israélite, protestante, musulmane...) vont pouvoir utiliser l'espace de liberté qui leur est très largement offert Depuis le 1er janvier 1989, la fédéralisation complète de l'enseignement a conduit à la mise en place de trois ministères de l'éducation distincts ayant l'entière maîtrise de l'enseignement pour chacune des communautés francophone, néeriandophone et germanophone. Seuls la durée de l'obligation scolaire, le régime des pensions des personnels et les conditions de délivrance des diplômes, font encore l'objet de réglementations nationales. Ici donc, non seulement la dévolution de compétence est totale entre l'Etat central et les communautés, mais un nouveau transfert de compétence s'opère entre les communautés et les multiples »pouvoirs organisateurs » des réseaux d'enseignement. En fait chaque système éducatif linguistique comporte trois types d'établissements : — * les établissements organisés et gérés par l'Etat et financés en totalité au moyen de son budget ; — les établissements publics subventionnés par l'Etat et gérés par les autorités provinciales ou communales ,· — les établissements * libres » subventionnés ou non par l'Etat, et dont beaucoup dépendent des églises... »

22 Les trois ministres de l'éducation détiennent donc le pouvoir organisateur de l'enseignement de l'Etat et veillent à l'application de la réglementation aux écoles * officielles » et aux écoles t libres » subventionnées. La régulation nationale est ici extrêmement faible : elle est le feit du corps d'inspection de l'Etat pour les seuls établissements d'enseignement de l'EtaL Une * surveillance » des autres établissements est certes confiée à ce même corps d'inspection, mais en fait les pouvoirs organisateurs ont pour les établissements qui les concernent leurs propres corps d'inspection. Aujourd'hui en Belgique l'enseignement d'Etat ne concerne environ que 40 % de la population scolarisée toutes communautés confondues. Notons que les trois ministères sont assistés d'un certain nombre de Conseils ou commissions dont un Conseil National des parents. On le voit la pression culturelle et linguistique s'est ici imposée au point de feire prévaloir des spécificités quasiment irréductibles. Il est permis de s'interroger sur les risques de disparition à terme du dispositif national d'éducation auxquels prédispose un tel fédéralisme. Si les tensions culturelles et linguistiques ont conduit la Belgique à un tel système fédéral, il convient de se garder de tout déterminisme visant à associer multilinguisme et pluralisme scolaire institutionnel. 3°/ - Luxembourg : Trilinguismo et unité. Le Grand Duché de Luxembourg apparaît en effet comme l'illustration exemplaire d'un système, scolaire unifié ayant su faire de son trilinguisme national un atout particulièrement précieux. Ici certes les limites géographiques tout autant que le petit nombre d'habitants incitaient à se garder de structures administratives séparées. Un peu plus de cinquante mille élèves sont scolarisés dans le Grand Duché, c'est dire qu'ici le Ministère de l'Education Nationale et de la jeunesse est unique, et fixe pour l'ensemble des établissements publics ou privés les modalités de fonctionnement et de contrôle. Ici, Etat, communes et organismes privés confessionnels ou non se partagent la gestion des établissements d'enseignement Le rôle des communes reste prépondérant dans l'enseignement primaire où elles ont en charge la nomination des enseignants. Les établissements privés sont relativement nombreux dans l'enseignement secondaire et dans l'éducation spécialisée. Etablissements publics et privés sont ici soumis aux mêmes exigences. Un comité supérieur de l'Education assiste le ministre. Au niveau des municipalités, des comités scolaires locaux sont chargés de la gestion des établissements et regroupent élus, représentants de l'église, de la population locale et des parents. Les enseignants ne peuvent siéger dans les comités scolaires locaux. Notons enfin qu'il n'existe pas d'enseignement universitaire à l'exception d'une année préparatoire à l'issue de laquelle les quelques milliers d'étudiants luxembourgeois vont poursuivre leurs études supérieures à l'étranger (France, Belgique, Allemagne, Suisse, Autriche...). Il faut dire que le système éducatif luxembourgeois dispensant dès les premières années de la scolarité un enseignement dans les trois langues (luxembourgeois, allemand, français) et offrant dans l'enseignement secondaire l'étude de l'anglais (ou du latin) dote chacun d'un capital linguistique nulle part atteint en Europe. Nous aurons l'occasion d'y revenir très largement. 4°/ - Pays-Bas : la liberté d'abord. Si l'on voulait avoir en Europe une illustration du principe de liberté d'enseignement au sens le plus large il faudrait à l'évidence se rendre aux Pays-Bas. Dans l'excellente étude que le Centre départemental de documentation pédagogique de l'Essonne a consacré à «l'Ecole des 12», les auteurs ont su en quelques mots résumer l'essentiel des grands principes qui inspirent la politique éducative néerlandaise à savoir : <r une école publique neutre, une liberté d'inspiration pour les écoles privées, une liberté de choix pour les familles, des pouvoirs publics neutres et distants qui veillent d'une manière constante sur l'enseignement tant public que privé... » La Constitution des Pays-Bas souligne explicitement cette philosophie de liberté éducative. Il faut dire que nous sommes ici au coeur de l'ancienne « République des Provinces Unies » qui eût à se défaire dès le XVIème siècle du joug pesant de l'Espagne catholique, puis épousa la Réforme et devint une confédération officiellement protestante. Les conquêtes napoléoniennes vont installer une domination française et dès 1806 un dualisme scolaire institutionnel se met en place : * écoles publiques (pour le bien de tous), écoles privées (pour les besoins particuliers) ». Les catholiques sont reconnus. Dès 1813, apparaît une école publique unique ouverte à tous et * appelée à conforter l'assise spirituelle de l'Etat, et le fondement moral de la religion chrétienne... » Très vite, les écoles privées se multiplient et avec elles commence aux Pays-Bas une nouvelle guerre de cent ans, guerre scolaire bien sûr. L'issue (constitution de 1887 remaniée en 1922) sera ce que nous savons, une stricte égalité financière, une totale liberté d'option. C'est la fameuse liberté d'inspiration entraînant par voie de conséquence <r la liberté de donner une éducation et un enseignement conforme à ses opinions ». L'observateur français reconnaîtra sans peine le fameux <r caractère propre » auquel se réfèrent notamment les tenants de l'école privée confessionnelle. La régulation appartient ici au Ministère de l'Education et des Sciences. Le financement d'Etat est identique pour les deux secteurs qui sont soumis aux mêmes obligations. Des conseils consultatifs assistent le ministre qui demande également, souligne l'étude déjà citée des Communautés européennes de 1987, <r au Conseil économique et social des recommandations concernant les aspects sociaux et économiques de l'enseignemenl.. ». En dépit de la régulation exercée par le pouvoir central, un certain nombre de. disparités ne manquent pas d'apparaître notamment dans le contenu des enseignements voire dans le contrôle des connaissances. Aujourd'hui un projet de loi est en cours d'adoption visant à faire prévaloir des normes nationales plus exigeantes. J.M. LECLERCQ et Ch. RAULT ont raison de souligner dans l'ouvrage déjà cité que <r si celui-ci était adopté, on pourrait alors voir s'instaurer aux Pays-Bas une situation assez analogue à celle du Danemark... »

23 S°/ - Danemark : une dévolution régulée aux pouvoirs locaux. Au Danemark, en effet, l'autorité du pouvoir central est bien réelle mais la répartition des compétences varie selon le type d'établissement et le niveau d'enseignement. Ainsi, des municipalités relèvent les * folkeskole », établissements intégrant enseignement primaire et premier cycle secondaire. Des autorités des quatorze comtés, relèvent les lycées (gymnasium). Les universités et autres établissements d'enseignement supérieur relèvent le plus souvent de la compétence de l'Etat. Pour chacun de ces niveaux d'enseignement existent aussi des établissements privés qui bénéficient de financements de l'Etat pouvant couvrir la totalité de leur budget L'Etat accorde aux municipalités des subventions globales mais ne décide pas de l'affectation de ces fonds scolaires, t Au niveau du comté et de la municipalité, précise l'étude des Communautés européennes déjà citée, les questions scolaires relèvent de la compétence des * conseils » respectifs qui sont des instances élues par la population. Les conseils nomment des commissions scolaires chargées de l'administration et de la gestion des écoles... » Notons que les conseils municipaux nomment les chefs d'établissements. Ces mêmes conseils municipaux sont placés par l'intermédiaire des conseils de comtés sous l'autorité du Ministère de l'Education pour tout ce qui relève de leurs compétences en matière d'éducation. On le voit les attributions de compétences à l'échelon local sont considérables, puisque c'est à ce niveau que se règlent les problèmes de carte scolaire, de constructions, de recrutement des enseignants, d'adjonctions spécifiques aux programmes officiels en fonction du contexte local. A l'évidence, nous sommes ici confrontés à une démarche qui tente de faire prévaloir les grandes options politiques, économiques et culturelles de l'Etat tout en incitant à la mise en oeuvre locale d'une très large initiative par une grande liberté dans le choix des solutions innovantes. L'extraordinaire souplesse du système éducatif danois vient sans doute aussi du feit qu'ici la démarche éducative personnalisée l'emporte largement sur le cursus normalisé. Ici, incontestablement c'est l'éducation que l'on préfère à l'institution école et c'est le cheminement qui tient lieu de chemin, loin des impatiences des évaluations normatives. Cela explique peut être le petit nombre d'établissements privés orientés d'ailleurs le plus souvent vers le recours à des méthodes pédagogiques originales. Si la décentralisation peut d'ores et déjà apparaître comme une caractéristique dominante de ces quelques pays de l'Europe du Nord, on mesure sans peine l'extraordinaire déclinaison de ses förmes. Entre le fédéralisme allemand fortement charpenté, le fédéralisme belge et ses fragmentations linguistiques, l'apologie de l'initiative locale néerlandaise au nom de la liberté souveraine de choix, et la dévolution large mais régulée aux pouvoirs locaux danois, la décentralisation apparaît sous de multiples visages. En réalité nous ne sommes pas au bout de nos perplexités puisque rien encore n'a été dit du système scolaire britannique. 6°/ - Le kaléidoscope britannique. Il faut en convenir rien n'est simple Outre-Manche en matière d'éducation. Certes ici l'unité linguistique n'est pas en cause (même si...), il n'en demeure pas moins que l'unité territoriale durement acquise n'a pu s'enraciner que par la prise en compte des spécificités culturelles (d'aucuns diraient nationales) de l'Angleterre, du Pays de Galles, de l'Ecosse, et de l'Irlande du Nord. Si nous ajoutons la grande diversité des sensibilités religieuses et les antagonismes toujours violents en Irlande du Nord entre catholiques et protestants, certes nous n'aurons encore rien expliqué véritablement mais nous serons mieux à même de comprendre le profond attachement britannique à une conception décentralisatrice du système éducatif. Notons d'abord qu'il s'agit d'un authentique héritage historique. Plus qu'ailleurs le pouvoir central s'est ici constamment tenu à distance de l'initiative éducative. Présentement c'est au travers d'un véritable kaléidoscope institutionnel qu'il faut tenter d'apercevoir les multiples facettes des systèmes éducatifs britanniques. Pas moins de quatre instances ministérielles pilotent cet ensemble : — Le Ministère de l'Education et de la Science d'Angleterre, — Le Département de l'Education du Ministère des Affaires Galloises, — Le Département écossais de l'Education, — Le Département de l'Education pour l'Irlande du Nord. C'est dire qu'ici la division territoriale a prévalu dans le partage des compétences. En fait le pouvoir central ne se trouve unifié en matière de compétence, que pour l'ensemble des Universités du Royaume, lesquelles jouissent par ailleurs d'une autonomie considérable. Ajoutons cependant que les autorités centrales fixent des objectifs nationaux, financent la recherche, et déterminent des normes minimales de besoins scolaires. Pour le reste, c'est à dire l'essentiel du quotidien, la véritable responsabilité appartient aux autorités territoriales (Local Education Authorities : LEA). On en dénombre près de 140 dans les villes, comtés ou bourgs-comtés tenus d'élire un Conseil de l'Education dont la moitié des membres au moins sont des membres élus issus de l'autorité territoriale (LEA) les autres étant cooptés parmi les experts et des spécialistes de l'enseignement Ce Conseil de l'Education a en charge non seulement la création, l'administration, l'entretien et le fonctionnement des écoles et collèges concernés mais aussi le recrutement et la gestion des personnels enseignants. Le financement des dépenses courantes est assuré conjointement par une subvention globale du pouvoir central et par des impôts locaux (notamment soulignons le au passage par l'impôt sur la fortune...)

24 Tout ce qui concerne la vie inteme de l'établissement et en particulier l'organisation pédagogique relève du Conseil d'administration de chaque école. Notons que les établissements relevant des autorités territoriales accueillent la quasi totalité de la population scolaire totale au Royaume Uni (entre 94 et 99 % selon les régions territoriales). L'ensemble de ces établissements pris en charge par les LEA est lui même composite, puisque l'on y trouve à la fois les écoles de comtés et les * voluntary school » subventionnées par les LEA mais créées par d'autres organisations notamment confessionnelles (Eglise d'Angleterre, Eglise catholique, autres confessions...) La Grande-Bretagne a entrepris de réformer sensiblement son dispositif par l'adoption en juillet 1988 d'une nouvelle loi sur l'Education. Si les risques de comparaisons n'étaient pas dangereux parce que toujours abusivement simplificateurs on pourrait sans doute dire qu'il y a dans la réforme de 1988 un cocktail d'influences venues des proches pays de l'Europe du Nord (Pays Bas, Danemark, Allemagne, Belgique) et peut être un zeste d'inspiration française. Qu'on en juge plutôt : la loi Baker de 1988 accorde aux parents le libre choix de l'établissement scolaire quelle que soit la sectorisation définie par les LEA. Elle accorde aussi à ces mêmes parents le droit à la suite d'un vote majoritaire de soustraire tel ou tel établissement à la tutelle d'une autorité territoriale pour placer cet établissement sous celle du Ministère de l'Education et de la Science, et bénéficier ainsi d'un financement équivalent mais d'un stamt de complète autonomie. Il ne faut pas voir là un désir absolu du pouvoir central de fédérer lui même des établissements d'enseignements mais tout au contraire la volonté de donner à la communauté éducative une autonomie plus large vis-à-vis des autorités territoriales. Cela est applicable d'ores et déjà en Angleterre et au Pays de Galles. Une centaine d'établissements auraient utilisé déjà ce c droit de sortie » (Opting out). Autre innovation, le Ministère anglais (DES) est désormais habilité à arrêter les normes d'effectifs pour chaque école et donc à limiter d'autant les attributions des autorités territoriales en matière de carte scolaire (il n'est pas interdit de penser au zeste d'inspiration française !). Enfin, et alors que la disparité la plus grande régnait dans la définition des contenus d'enseignement la loi nouvelle se propose d'instaurer un * National Curriculum » sorte de cadre minimum obligatoire fixant la liste des matières à enseigner dans toutes les écoles publiques pour les élèves de cinq à seize ans ainsi qu'une série d'évaluations obligatoires afin de mesurer si les objectifs prévus ont été ou non atteints. Cela rappelle certes des mesures qui sont aujourd'hui devenues familières aux Français, mais la loi Baker a précédé d'un an la loi française d'Orientation de juillet 1989. Plus grande liberté donnée aux usagers, plus sensible encadrement des dépenses prévisibles par de nouvelles nonnes nationales en matière de carte scolaire, enfin totale autonomie financière des établissements dotés d'une enveloppe globale annuelle non affectée, la Grande-Bretagne tente de corriger les dérives d'une décentralisation devenue incohérente et coûteuse, et s'inspire d'une sorte de centralisme rampant qui n'est pas sans rappeler certaines pratiques chères à l'Europe du Sud ! La régulation centrale reste assurée par le corps d'inspection de Sa Majesté mais il y a des inspections différentes pour l'Angleterre, le Pays de Galles, l'Ecosse et l'Irlande du Nord. Les structures scolaires écossaises sont quelque peu différentes, mais les modalités de fonctionnement sont équivalentes. 7°/ - La dyarchie irlandaise. Reste à évoquer le cas original de la République d'Irlande. L'Irlande apparaît en effet comme un cas singulier tant se mêlent et s'enchevêtrent en matière d'éducation le centralisme administré et une dévolution de compétences aux pouvoirs locaux, mais plus encore les influences conjointes du pouvoir politique et du pouvoir religieux. C'est là bien sûr un legs de l'histoire. Sous la domination anglaise, le système scolaire irlandais résidait essentiellement dans un ensemble d'initiatives locales volontaires contrôlées et gérées par ceux là mêmes qui les avaient suscitées. L'Etat britannique ne prenait, pas plus là qu'ailleurs, l'initiative d'ouvrir des écoles, ce fut donc essentiellement l'église catholique ou les confessions religieuses qui durent y pourvoir. La Constitution irlandaise de 1937 souligne cette importance accordée à l'initiative privée : * L'Etat reconnaît que l'éducateur premier et naturel de l'enfant est la famille et que tes parents sont libres d'assurer cette éducation soil dans leur foyer, soit dans ¡es écoles privées, soit dans les écoles reconnues ou établies par l'Etal II est du devoir de l'Etat d'assurer une éducation primaire gratuite et de compléter et aider dans la mesure du possible les initiatives privées ou coopératives ». En Irlande les écoles primaires ou <r nationales » ne sont pas des écoles publiques, mais des écoles locales sous protection et contrôle local, subventionnées par l'Etat Le concept de t protection » peut ici surprendre si l'on oublie qu'il s'agit essentiellement de la tutelle qu'exerce le <r Patron » personne ou organisme à l'initiative de la création de l'école et qui, à ce titre, sollicite l'aide financière de l'Etat II s'agit essentiellement de l'èvèque de la confession concernée. Jusqu'en 1975, chaque école était administrée par un directeur, le plus souvent un ecclésiastique, nommé par le <r Patron ». Depuis des conseils de direction ont été créés où siègent représentants du Patron, des parents, des enseignants. Ces conseils ont en charge la gestion et l'entretien des établissements et procèdent à la nomination des enseignants sous réserve toutefois d'approbation du Ministre de l'Education. L'enseignement primaire est donc tirés largement confessionnel et rares sont encore les écoles multi co nfession- nelles. Les écoles secondaires sont des écoles privées le plus souvent administrées par les communautés religieuses mais quasi- intégralement financées par les deniers publics. Si l'Etat est donc ici très largement le payeur, à défaut d'être l'unique commandeur, il entend résolument être le contrôleur. Il fixe un programme commun d'enseigne ment détermine les qualifications des enseignants, exerce sur l'ensemble du système son pouvoir d'inspection, fixe les règles générales de fonctionnement, bref, on le voit l'Etat se veut interventionniste et ne s'en prive pas. En feit toutes les décisions sont prises en étroite collaboration avec les autorités religieuses, notamment les évéchès. L'ensemble du dispositif est fortement marqué par l'influence confessionnelle, et la dyarchie autorité civile/autorité religieuse est telle qu'on a ici quelque difficulté à percevoir la difference entre public et privé. Alléger la fiscalité des entreprises rendra les pla cements sous forme d'actions plus attractifs. Faire disparaître les freins qui entravent encore la mobilité des capitaux Ce sont probablement les intermédiaires financiers qui procéderont à l'allocation européenne de l'épargne. A cet égard, il convient de poursuivre la levée des obstacles qui peuvent entraver la diversification internationale des pla cements. Le récent projet de directive sur les institutions de retraite s'inscrit directement dans cette perspective. L'organisation des marchés boursiers européens devrait également contribuer à cette meilleure adéquation entre l'épargne et l'investissement au niveau européen.

28 Réduire les disparités fiscales en Europe Trop de disparités fiscales dans le traitement aussi bien des placements, des revenus des placements, du patrimoine, de la transmission des patrimoines, etc., demeurent aujourd'hui 1 . Dans tous les cas, elles introduisent des distorsions préjudiciables à une allocation optimale des flux d'épargne en Europe qui de vrait n'obéir qu'à des critères économiques et financiers. Par ailleurs la fiscalité sur l'épargne devrait conduire à privilégier systématiquement l'épargne stable, contractuelle, longue. Introduction A smoke screen is hanging across the European Community. Although the screen is not as impenetrable as the erstwhile iron curtain, the parties on either side of it are engaging in a cold war. In the northern camp, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom have dug in. Belgium, France, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, Portugal and Spain are entrenched in the southern camp. The issue deeply dividing both camps concerns the structure of the tobacco excise. The excise can be levied at a fixed amount per quantity (specific rate), a fixed percentage of the retail price (ad valorem rate), or some combination of these rates. Because tobacco products are taxed exceedingly high, 1 the choice of the rate has important consequences for the revenue of the excise, the efficacy of the levy, the quality of the product, and, last but not least, the completion of the internal market. A specific rate is more favorable to the treasury, is more effective in internalizing the harmful effects of smoking, does not influence the quality of tobacco products, and accords better with the aims of the internal market. An ad valorem rate protects the cultivation of inferior tobacco, but implies a less regressive distribution of the tax burden. The northern member states want to retain an important role for the specific rate. The southern member states want to make the excise almost exclusively ad valorem. This article reports on the battle being waged around the cigarette excise. The next section begins with an analysis of the rate structure. The sector provides a good case study as it has been subject to major institutional change, which has resulted in institutional divergence between Britain and France; moreover, it has become a strategic sector for Western economies, not only expanding in its own right but also becoming a vital resource for a wide range of other sectors, including finance, tourism, retailing and parts of manufacturing industry. Institutionalist theories claim that institutions and policies are strongly related: if institutional arrangements differ, so do policies, and the economic results of policy, termed "economic outcomes". It is this contention that is scrutinised here: if the institutional arrangements governing the making of certain types of decision become increasingly different, has this led to a corresponding growing dissimilarity in the substantive results of those same decisions, or have other factors, excluded from ¡nstitutionalist approaches, been important? The questions being asked is thus: have differing, and indeed diverging, institutional arrangements in Britain and France given rise to contrasting and divergent economic outcomes? The approach taken is that public policy analysis: the focus is on the organisation of the State, and the way in which public policy decisions are taken. Thus it differs from an economic analysis or a financial approach: no attempt is made to judge whether Britain or France have made more or less economically efficient choices, nor whether network operators are more or less financially effective (2). Therefore the first task is to briefly set the theoretical context used, namely that of "institutionalism" in public policy analysis (section I). The article then sets out how "institutional arrangements" became increasingly different between 1969 and 1989 (section II). It describes how the organisation of the sector and the role of the State evolved in the two countries. Specifically, it points out how the formal rules governing certain major types of policy decision in network operation concerning matters such expansion of the telecommunications network, investment, prices, and employment, became very different in the two countries. (5]

34 In the third section various indicators of the economic results of policy are examined. These are chosen in that they relate to the framework of policy-making, and particularly the various categories of decision analysed in the second section. Hence they allow the hypothesis that different formal rules at sectoral level governing policy-making in certain fields lead to contrasting economic outcomes in those same fields to be tested. It is suggested that despite increasing institutional divergence over the period 1969-89, many of the economic outcomes examined show a similar trend in terms of the direction of change. Moreover, most of the differences in economic outcomes have narrowed over the period -ie there has been convergence, not divergence. Nevertheless, significant contrasts remained in 1989 between the two countries in terms of absolute levels. Furthermore, there have been differences in the speed and path of development over the twenty year period. The conclusion then discusses possible explanations of the results found. It is suggested that technological and economic factors, which are omitted in institutionalist' approaches to policy, may have been the major cause of the similarity of directions of change and the narrowing of differences. Institutional factors are useful, particularly in assisting explanations of the differences found. But, institutionalist approaches require greater specification of the conditions under which they are applicable, whilst future models of policy should include technological and economic factors, which may have a major impact on economic outcomes. ■ Conclusion Between 1969 and 1989 the institutional arrangements in network operation increasingly differed, both in terms of the general organisation of the sector and the framework for policy-making, and the rules for taking certain specific types of policy decision. The hypothesis set out at the beginning of the article was that if institutionalist approaches are a powerful explanation at sectoral level, increasingly different institutional arrangements would result in a corresponding divergence of policies and economic outcomes. But analysis of indicators of the major economic outcomes in network operation in Britain and France reveals a rather different picture. Similar trends are observed in the evolution of most economic outcomes. The extent and economic size of the telephone network have been characterised by rapid growth; the networks have been modernised by the introduction of new technology; labour productivity has risen, and the proportion of total revenue consumed by employment costs has declined; tariffs for connection, rental and trunk and international calls, have fallen in real terms, whilst those for local calls have risen overall; quality of service has improved. The direction of change has only differed significantly in one case: financial outcomes, where BT's profitability rose, as the proportion of income consumed by financial and depreciation costs fell, but the DGT's/FT's fell. Moreover, the extent of change has often been striking and large-scale, as in the cases of expansion of the networks and income, modernisation, labour productivity, tariff changes and improvements in quality. Furthermore, differences in the absolute levels of many of the indicators have narrowed between 1969 and 1989 -i.e. there has been convergence, not divergence. Thus by the late 1980s, the extent of the telephone network, its economic size, investment levels, modernisation, total employment, revenue per employee, and overall tariffs and the prices of several types of call, had either become similar or were marked by a greatly reduced differential between the two countries. Divergence has been limited to three matters: financial outcomes (the profits of the network operators and their financial costs), which may have been influenced more by differing financial structures and accounting principles than economic differences; the number of main lines per employee; connection and rental charges.

35 This evidence runs counter to the claim for the crucial importance of institutions for economic outcomes, at least at sectoral level. In the face of institutional divergence, the indicators chosen reveal the operation of similar and large-scale trends of change, and a lessening of differences in several of the outcomes examined over the period. However, dissimilarities have also existed between the two countries, which might be used as evidence for at least some influence of institutions on economic outcomes. Two categories can be distinguished. Firstly, there have been important contrasts in the speed of change and the path of development between the two countries. The rate of growth of the network in France has been higher than in Britain. Digital switching has been introduced more rapidly than in Britain, and labour productiviy has risen faster in terms of main lines per employee. Connection and rental charges have decreased by a greater proportion in France than in Britain. Secondly, despite convergence, certain differences still existed in 1988 which whilst often smaller than in 1970, were nevertheless significant; these concerned the level and composition of network operation income, modernisation, profitability and financial costs, the number of main lines per employee, and the prices of some individual services. Two questions then arise. Firstly, can alternative explanations of the similar directions of change and narrowing of differences be found? Secondly, given the results found, including the dissimilarities between the two countries, what explanatory power and utility can be ascribed to institutionalist theories? One possible explanation of the results found is that institutions, at a higher level than that of the sector, have been a vital determinant of outcomes. But, national institutions in Britain and France have been very different, and indeed are usually presented as at the opposite ends of the spectrum within Western Europe (HALL, 1986; ZYSMAN, 1983). Whilst international organisations, such as the ITU (International Telecommunications Union), or CEPT (Conference of European Posts and Telecommunications), have existed, their role has been mostly confined to international communications, and they have had almost no powers and influence over matters such as investment, modernisation or the pricing of national services. Similar Government policies, ambitions and strategies constitute a second possible explanation. However, the empirical evidence runs counter to such an explanation. Governments in Britain and France have been of contrasting political natures for most of the period. Moreover, their strategies for telecommunications have been very different. During the 1970s, France pursued a policy of rapid expansion and modernisation, and attempted to develop a world lead in network operation, based on the "grandprojet" model of economic success (COHEN, 1992), whereas British Governments concentrated on price restraint by the PO and control of investment to meet public expenditure and borrowing targets. In the 1980s, French Governments (including the Right 1986-88) emphasised the public service character of the DGT/France Télécom, whereas the Conservative Governments in Britain pursued a strategy of privatisation, greater autonomy of BT from detailed Governmental control and encouragement of a "commercial" approach modelled on the private sector, drawing on ideas of deregulation frequently developed in the US. Instead the most powerful and straight-forward explanation of similar trends and convergence in economic outcomes is provided by the effects of technological and economic factors. Demand for telephony has increased, both from households and from businesses. Major sectors, including tourism, finance and retailing have developed specialised uses for the telecommunications system. The increased demand for and usage of telecommunications have resulted in pressure and incentives on Governments and network operators for growth, modernisation and investment, and also for lower prices.

36 On the supply side, technological developments, notably electronic switching and optical fibre cable, have offered drastically reduced costs (1), better quality services and higher labour productivity. Lower costs have allowed network operators to enjoy both higher profits and to offer lower prices. Thus strong economic incentives have existed for the use of new technology. But, the introduction of such technology to reap the economic benefits available has required large scale investment. Moreover, the new technology has weakened natural monopoly in network operation. The cost of alternative networks has fallen, making "bypass" of the public switched telephone network easier, notably by use of private satellites for international communications, and private networks or packet switched networks for trunk calls. At the same time, new technology has altered the structure of costs, which have become less related to distance. Hence, if prices remained unchanged, a growing disparity with costs would have developed, especially in long distance and international communications, creating an incentive for users to "bypass" the public network. Thus network operators have faced economic pressure to meet demand and to lower prices for long distance transmission, or risk competition for their profits and monopoly position. However, emphasis on the important role of technological and economic factors does not mean that institutions can be ignored. The results found may relate to the nature of the case studied, namely network operation over a twenty year period in two particular countries. It is possible that institutional factors have an impact, but over a longer period, and hence the effects of institutional divergence will be seen in the future; nevertheless, the evidence thus far is of convergence, not divergence, and even if such a hypothesis were correct, the question would remain of why it took so long of institutional divergence to influence economic outcomes. The conclusions also only concern network operation in Britain and France: it may be that different results would be obtained if other countries, sectors of parts of the telecommunications sector, such as the host of new services other than fixed link voice telephony, were examined. It is possible that institutions are more important in fields in which technological and economic factors are more stable, or less powerful, allowing more scope for institutional factors to produce effects, or in larger countries, where policy choices affect technological and economic developments (1) or if there is greater variance in institutional arrangements (2). This would require a wider study, which would seek to identify why certain institutional changes in specific countries and in particular sectors do or do not influence economic outcomes; a variety of conditions could be considered, including the technological and economic nature of the sector, the type of institutional reform and the flexibility of national institutional arrangements. However, such a study is beyond the scope of the present article, which examines a strategic sector in which, a priori, institutionalist claims might be expected to be validated. At the specific level of network operation, examination of institutions provides an important element in the explanation of the differences found in economic outcomes. These differences have principally concerned the contrasting speed of changes and paths of development of the two networks in 1970, and the remaining contrasts that existed in 1988. The speed of change and path of development are closely related to the backwardness and under-development of the French network in 1970 compared to the British one. The causes for this lay in the history of telecommunications after 1945, including institutional arrangements. Of particular importance was the low priority given to telecommunications in the 'Plans" between 1946 and the late 1960s, whereby only limited investment spending was allocated to the DGT (LIBOIS, 1983). No institutional equivalent to the Commissariat général au Plan existed in Britain, so that investment expenditure by the PO depended on a variety of factors, including the existing level of expenditure, the political influence of the Postmaster General, and the capacity of the PO to finance its own investment (PITT, 1980).

37 The backwardness of the telecommunications system in 1969 gave rise to strong pressures for rapid growth and modernisation. Institutional arrangements, in combination with the ambitions of policy-makers, were important in permitting this to happen. The new methods of raising finance for capital expenditure developed, particularly the CNT and the "sociétés de financement du téléphone", were a significant policy instrument for this: between 1970 an 1979 21.2% of investment was financed by the CNT and 15.1% by the "sociétés de financement" (LE DIBERDER, 1981). It was the sudden and massive increase in investment which resulted in a contrasting path of development in France compared with Britain, whose network enjoyed steady growth. The very fast growth of the network in France also had consequences for other economic outcomes, and helps explain some of the differences found, both in the pattern of development, and absolute levels in 1988: it was easier and more commercially viable to introduce digital switching, since new exchanges were being installed, rather than existing ones replaced; rapid growth financed by borrowing resulted in high interest costs, with consequences for probability and the composition of costs, whereas BT could finance a greater proportion of investment from internally- generated funds; a high level of digitalisation permitted higher labour productivity. Institutional factors are also useful in explaining some of the other differences found in absolute levels of the indicators examined. Part of the DGT's higher investment may be explained by its use to support "grands projets" in the 1980s, notably the "Plan Câble" and the satellite programme. The earlier introduction of digital switching was due to the French lead in the development of such switches, which may have been assisted by the institutional position of the DGT and CNET, and their links with CIT-Alcatel. The dissimilarities in prices found are, in part at least, explicable by the institutional framework. The commercial orientation given to the PO encouraged it to set prices closer to costs. Then in the 1980s, the end of BT's monopoly endangered its profitable trunk traffic, increasing pressure for "re-balancing", between trunk and local calls, which was made possible by the fact that the price formula of "RPI-3%" applied to a "basket" of services, and created incentives for the cost of connection and rental charges to be set closer to costs. Moreover, as a private company with publicly quoted shares, BT has faced pressure to produce high profits. No such pressures applied in France; indeed, the powers of the PTT minister allowed connection and rental charges to be reduced to offset unpopular increases in usage charges, levied in order to raise revenue for the "prélèvements" for the general budget (1). Differences in tariffs are themselves a partial explanation of contrasts in sources of income', and of profits. Explanations of economic outcomes must include institutional factors, and indeed also the aims and strategies of policy-makers who fashion institutions. But, institutionalist theories fall to specify the conditions under which institutions may influence economic outcomes and omit technological and economic developments, whose effects may be greater than those of institutions. In the case examined, it appears that divergent institutional arrangements in Britain and France over the period 1969-89 failed to prevent economic outcomes from moving in the similar directions and differences between many of them from narrowing. It would seem that the explanatory power of institutions in this case is much greater in dealing with the path of development, speed of change, and the differences that remained in 1989, whereas other factors are more powerful explanations of the directions of change and convergence of outcomes. In particular, it is suggested, the driving force behind these developments has been provided by technological and economic factors. They have greatly altered the nature of network operation. Their effects can be linked to pressures and incentives on the main actors in the sector, and to the major economic outcomes.

38 Technological and economic factors would appear to be an essential part of explanation of public policy and economic outcomes in telecommunications. Indeed, such a conclusion may apply to be increasing number of sectors whose technological and economic characteristics are changing rapidly. Perhaps the chief empirical default of institutionalist analyses is that, although dealing with industrial and economic policy they omit such factors. This runs the risk of an unbalanced concentration on national differences, which may be limited relative to the overall movement of a sector and may obscure elements of similarity between countries. Thus institutionalist models need to offer greater specifiticy concerning the phenomena they can usefully attempt to explain and the conditions under which they operate, whilst future models of policy need to include technological and economic developments, relating them to the interests and behaviour of actors. * * * **

RESULTS OF EMPIRICAL ANALYSIS These propositions were examined in the context of a comparative analysis of the role played by state-societal arrangements in changes in international competitiveness in the five largest industrial capitalist countries - the United States, Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany, France and Britain - in three industries - steel, motor vehicles and semiconductors - since the Second World War. These three industries were chosen to represent three distinct waves of innovation in industrial technology and to test the proposition that there is more consistency in state-societal arrangements within nations across industries than there is within industries across nations. One of the key findings was that international competitiveness in steel, motor vehicles and semiconductors has been strongly dependent on the diffusion of new technologies. In the case of steel, the new technologies were basic-oxygen processing and continuous casting. In the case of motor vehicles, the new tech nologies were just-in-time (or kanban) production systems and, later, new forms of factory automation. In the case of semiconductors, the new technologies were the product and process technologies necessary to move from one genera tion of semiconductors to another (for example, from transistors to integrated circuits and from integrated circuits to large-scale integrated circuits). Those countries that were successful in innovating and diffusing these technologies earliest were most likely to increase their share of world produc tion, to experience high rates of productivity growth, to maintain or increase employment, and to experience fewer financial crises. Overall, innovation was not as important as diffusion. Even if domestic firms were not first in commercia lizing a new technology, the national industries that widely adopted new techno logies in a timely manner had a distinct competitive advantage over those that did not, independently of other presumably important variables like average wages. SUMMING UP How can we explain changes in international competitiveness among the major industrial nations in the last twenty years or so? The answer lies in the political and social institutions that establish the fundamental relationships among government, business and labour in each society. These state-societal arrange ments vary substantially from country to country. Variations in state-societal arrangements affect competitiveness mainly through their effect on the creation and diffusion of new technologies.

41 It is ironic that systems with only one major dominant social actor in the realm of industrial policy (Britain, France and the United States) tend to do worse in post-war international competition than systems with two (Germany and Japan). A coalition of either the state and business (Japan) or business and labour (Germany) seems to be more conducive to the diffusion of new technologies than one-actor dominance. One might think that a business- dominant system like that of the United States would be ideal for maintaining competitiveness, but that is not so. In a technological age, when the weakness of labour is the result of a low societal commitment to raising the level of skills in the work-force, there will be extensive resistance to the introduction of new technologies in factories and offices. Similarly, one might think that systems with state dominance, such as France, would do well in international competition. But a strong state acting alone without strong allies in the private sector will be quite limited in its ability to anticipate shifts in markets and to respond correctly to them. Thus, we are left with a choice between two 'models', currently embodied in the German and Japanese systems. I have argued here that the United States and Britain should opt for a German-style system, while France might pursue a Japanese-style approach. I have indicated that certain problematic features remain in both the German and Japanese approaches. In any case, I expect variations in state-societal arrangements to persist and for these variations to continue to be a source of debate within and between countries. One could argue convincingly, based on historical evidence, that changes in state-societal arrangements are at the centre of all domestic debates and that it takes more than relative economic decline to change the outcome of such debates. The increasing bitterness of economic disputes among the major industrialized coun tries, however, creates an important incentive for them to consider all possible mechanisms for reducing international economic tensions - even domestic change. * * * ** (6)

Under the exemption method dividends from a qualifying subsidiary are exempt from tax altogether. Under the credit method dividends received form part of taxable income of the parent company and a credit is given for any with­ holding and underlying tax paid by the subsidiary in the other member state up to a maximum amount of the corresponding tax payable in the parent company's state. Belgium, Denmark, France, Luxembourg and the Netherlands already exempt div­ idends from qualifying foreign subsidiaries in their domestic legislation. Strictly speaking, the Belgium system of exemption does not comply with the Directive as the dividend is initially comprised in taxable income and then a deduc­ tion equal to 95 percent of the dividend income is allowed as an expense. However, if there is insufficient income to absorb the deduction or if the Belgium company is in a loss position then the dividend deduction is permanently lost as it may not be carried forward or carried back as part of a loss. Italy has opted for the exemption method. Germany has opted for the credit method unless the dividends are already exempt under a double taxation agreement. 48 Germany presently exempts all dividends received from qualifying subsidiaries in other EC member states. In effect, Germany has an exemption method for purposes of the Directive. Ireland and Spain have opted for the credit method. Under existing legislation, the United Kingdom operates the credit method for foreign withholding and underlying taxes. B. Minimum participation The Directive attributes the status of parent company at least to a company which, inter alia, has a minimum holding of 25 percent in the capital of a company of another member state. There is no requirement that the holding be maintained for any minimum period of time. However, a member state may require a minimum holding period of at least two years. Under the participation exemption regime in Belgium there is no minimum participation requirement, so Belgium did not need to amend its legislation in this respect. In Denmark, a minimum participation of 25 percent is al ready provided for under existing law. In France, the present participation exemption regime requires that the value of the shareholding be equal to at least 150 million francs or represent at least ten percent of the sub sidiary's share capital. Consequently, France has made no alterations to its existing law in this respect. The existing German system for the taxation of dividends from foreign subsidiaries provides for a minimum participa tion of ten percent. Under the participation exemption system in Luxembourg, there is a requirement for a minimum shareholding often per cent or a minimum value of 50 million francs. The Dutch participation exemption system normally requires a shareholding of at least five percent. However, the partici pation exemption does not apply to shareholdings which con stitute a portfolio investment or to shareholdings which are held as inventory. The Dutch government has amended its law to comply with the Directive as far as portfolio invest ments are concerned, and a 25 percent shareholding in such a company will now qualify for exemption. However, no such change has been made for shareholdings held as inventory. Presumably this position is defended by the Dutch Govern ment on the grounds that domestic anti-abuse provisions are not precluded by· the Directive. UK domestic law requires a ten percent shareholding. C. Minimum holding period The Directive requires no minimum holding period, or alter natively an uninterrupted period of at least two years. In this respect Germany, by maintaining a minimum period of at least 12 months prior to the end of the year in which the div idend is received, has not, strictly speaking, complied with the terms of the Directive. Luxembourg has the same 12 month rule and has not amended its legislation. The Italian Parliament has recommended a minimum holding period of one year. All other member states have either opted for no holding period, a minimum two year holding period or a mix ture of the two. II. DIVIDENDS PAID TO AN EC PARENT COMPANY The Directive provides that profits distributed by a subsidiary to its parent company be exempt from withholding tax at least where the parent holds a minimum of 25 percent of the capital of the subsidiary. Special derogations to this rule are accorded to Germany, Greece and Portugal. Germany is allowed to maintain a five percent withholding tax until 1 July 1996 so long as it charges corporation tax on distributed profits at a rate at least 11 percent lower than the rate applicable to retained profits. Greece may continue its present system of withholding taxes as dividends paid are allowed as a deduction in calculating taxable income. How ever, the rate of withholding tax must not exceed the rate pro vided for in double taxation agreements. Portugal may con tinue to levy withholding taxes until 31 December 1999 but subject to existing double taxation agreements concluded with other member states the rate of withholding tax may not exceed 15 percent during the first five years and ten percent during the last three years. It should also be noted that under existing legislation in the United Kingdom and Ireland there is no withholding tax on the payment of dividends to foreign residents. The only country that has lowered the qualifying minimum participation in its implementing legislation is Germany. According to new Article 44 d(3) of the Income Tax Act, the minimum participation of 25 percent may be lowered to ten percent provided that a tax exemption or a tax credit is grant ed in the parent company's jurisdiction for the German cor porate income tax suffered on the distributed profits, and such country exempts from withholding tax distributions of profits made to a German parent company with a sharehold ing of at least ten percent. In its implementing legislation, Germany has amended its refund procedure for withholding taxes on dividends paid to qualifying parent companies. If a parent company has obtained an exemption certificate from the German Finance Ministry the German payor may apply the lower Directive or treaty rate immediately upon payment. Otherwise the stan dard 25 percent withholding tax rate will be initially applied and the recipient must apply for a refund. As mentioned above, the Directive does not lay down any minimum holding period in order to qualify for the reduced withholding. However, the Directive by way of derogation allows a member state to require a minimum holding period of at least two years. This two year option has been taken up by Denmark, France, Luxembourg and Spain. Belgium, Ger many, Italy and the Netherlands have opted for a minimum holding period of at least one year. Such minimum period is not actually permitted by the Directive.

49 III. TAX CREDITS/PREPAYMENTS The Directive makes clear in Article 7 that the term "with holding tax" does not cover an advance payment or prepay ment of corporation tax which is made in connection with a distribution of profits to a parent company. The United King dom and Ireland operate an advance corporation tax system and both Italy and France have a prepayment system which applies to the distribution of profits which have not borne the normal rate of tax. The Directive also does not affect the application of provi sions relating to the payment of tax credits attaching to divi dends. There are four member states that grant refunds of tax credits in certain circumstances to non-residents, i.e. France, Ireland, Italy and the United Kingdom. These tax credit refunds are reduced by an amount called a withholding lax which is based on the combined value of the dividend and the tax credit. It has been suggested in sonic press reports that such reduction of the tax credit is contrary to the Directive. I lowcvcr, this writer is of the opinion that the reduction of the tax credit refund is permitted by the Directive by virtue of Article 7 (2). IV. OTHER COMMENTS It is interesting to note that France in ils implementing legis lation has made it a condition for obtaining exemption from withholding tax that the foreign parent company must not, by virtue of a tax treaty, be entitled to a payment from the French Treasury which is equal to the tax credit (avoir fiscal) or equal to a fraction of the tax credit which is greater than the rate of withholding tax on dividends provided for by the same treaty. In the opinion of the writer France's position cannot be supported by the wording of the Directive. This provision may cause problems for Italian parent companies under the new France/Italy treaty because of the provisions for the refund of tax credits, and to Dutch parent companies, for example, because of the provisions for the refund of the pré compte in the France/Netherlands treaty. V ANTI-ABUSE PROVISIONS Article 1(2) of the Direclive states that "this Directive shall not preclude the application of domestic or agreement-based provisions required for the prevention of fraud or abuse". Thus the Direclive may be overridden by provisions in the domestic law of any member state and, for example, by any provisions in a double taxation agreement. In implementing the Directive, France has introduced an anti- Directive shopping provision into its Tax Code which states that if a parent company in another member state is con trolled directly or indirectly by non-residents of the EC then France will deny the benefits of the Directive to that parent company on the payment of dividends by a French sub sidiary. A defence is available to the parent company if it can demonstrate that the relationship with its subsidiary does not have as its main object or one of its main objects the obtain ing of the reduced withholding under the Directive. Spain has introduced a similar provision which denies the benefits of the Directive to parent companies located in other member states where the majority of the voting rights of such parent companies are held directly or indirectly by persons who are not residents of the EC. As in the case of France, a defence is available if the parent company can demonstrate that it conducts a business activity related to the activities of its subsidiary or its purpose is to manage and control its sub sidiary and it has adequate human and material resources to do so or can evidence that it was established for valid eco nomic reasons and not for taking undue advantage of the new legislation. Two of the six criteria set by the Italian Parliament for the implementation of the Directive specificly mention the with drawal of Directive benefits in the event of fraud or abuse, i.e. in respect of the exemption of dividends received from EC subsidiaries and a general withdrawal of all benefits that may arise from the implementation of the Directive in the event of fraud or abuse. Belgium introduced anti-abuse provisions in 1989 in respect of the receipt of dividends from foreign subsidiaries. These provisions were extended when the Directive was imple mented to include an anti-conduit provision which is designed to prevent the use of an intermediate holding com pany. Broadly, the new provisions state that if dividends were received directly by the Belgium parent and the exemption would not apply then the redistribution of the dividends by the intermediate holding company would similarly not quali fy for exemption. The Netherlands has made proposals to amend its Dividend Tax Act so that generally there will be no withholding tax on the payment of dividends by a Dutch company to an EC par ent company. However, one of the conditions to qualify for the reduced withholding is that the EC parent is not preclud ed from claiming reduced dividend withholding tax by virtue of anti-abuse provisions contained in an existing double tax ation agreement between the Netherlands and the country of residence of the parent company.' It would appear that cur rently this anti-abuse provision has limited scope as no treaty signed by the Netherlands with any other EC country has such an anti-abuse provision, with the exception of the treaty with Luxembourg and then only with respect to Luxembourg holding companies which, in any case, are already excluded from the Directive. The Netherlands has also made proposals to make amend ments to its participation exemption regime which covers, inter alia, the receipt of dividends from foreign qualifying companies. One of the conditions to qualify is that the partic ipation in the foreign company must not be considered a port folio investment. This requirement will be withdrawn in future. However, the requirement that the shareholding must not be held as inventory will remain. The retention of this condition by the Dutch government has been justified by its domestic provisions for the prevention of abuse.

50 VI. EXTENSION OF THE DIRECTIVE TO ENTITIES NOT MENTIONED IN THE ANNEX The Directive only covers entities which take one of the forms specifically mentioned in the Annex. For example, in the case of the United Kingdom it covers companies incorpo rated under UK law, and in the case of France it covers com panies known as "société anonyme', "société en commandite par actions", société à responsabilité limitée" and industrial and commercial establishments and undertakings. The scope of this particular provision of the Directive has been extend ed by several member states either because of an existing provision in the domestic law of a particular member state or by express inclusion in its implementing legislation. Under the Belgium participation exemption regime, divi dends received by a Belgium company from a participation in a non-resident company which is subject in its local jurisdic tion to a tax similar to the Belgium corporate income tax will qualify for exemption. Therefore if a Belgium company is a shareholder in a French SNC (Société en nom collectif) which has elected to be subject to corporate tax in France then a distribution from the SNC to the Belgium shareholder will qualify for exemption in Belgium notwithstanding that an SNC is not listed as a qualifying company in the Annex. Under the Dutch participation exemption regime, it is suffi cient that a foreign subsidiary be subject to a tax on profits in the country in which it is resident. The comments above regarding a French SNC would equally apply here. Germany will also apply the reduced rate of withholding tax on distributions by any entity which falls within the provi sions of Article 1 ( 1 ) of the German Corporate Income Tax Act and which is not included in the Annex provided the country in which the parent company is resident grants a tax exemption or credit for German corporate tax suffered on the distribution, and such country exempts from withholding tax any distributions made to a German parent company. In Spain's implementing legislation, the Ministry of Finance is authorized to extend the provisions of the Directive to par ent and subsidiary companies which take a form other than that mentioned in the Annex provided reciprocal treatment is accorded by the other member state. The United Kingdom grants unilateral reliefin respect of tax payable under the law of any territory outside the United Kingdom. It is not necessary that the entity be listed in the Annex in order to qualify for this treatment. VII. VOTING RIGHTS Under Article 3(1) of the Directive, a subsidiary is defined as a company in which a company of another member state has a holding of at least 25 percent of its capital. Article 3 (2) grants member states the option, by means of a bilateral agreement, of replacing the 25 percent holding requirement in the capital by a holding of 25 percent of voting rights. The majority of member states did not take up this option and left the qualifying requirement at 25 percent of share capital. Ireland, however, provides in its implementating legislation that the voting requirement may be substituted for the hold ing requirement where a bilateral agreement so provides. UK domestic legislation already provides for a voting test and the Consultative Document issued by the Inland Revenue does not contain any proposal to change this to a simple shareholding requirement. The Netherlands also opted for the voting rights test in instances where a tax treaty provides such a test for reducing the source taxation of dividends. VIII. CHARGES/CAPITAL LOSS DEDUCTION Article 4(2) of the Directive provides that each member state should retain the option of providing that any charges relating to a shareholding and any losses resulting from the distribu tion of the profits of the subsidiary may not be deducted from the taxable profits of the parent company. Where the man agement costs relating to a shareholding are fixed at a flat rate, the rate may not exceed five percent of the dividends received. No member state in its implementing legislation has introduced any specific provisions on the non-deductibil- ity of charges relating to a shareholding. Generally such costs are allowed as a deduction in each member state with the exception of the following: - Under existing legislation, France restricts the deduc tibility of costs relating to a qualifying shareholding. A company may either exclude all associated costs or alter natively add back in its tax computation a lump sum amount equal to five percent of the exempt dividends. - The Netherlands, under its participation exemption, does not allow the deduction of any costs attributable to a qualifying shareholding. - Luxembourg has a partial restriction on the deduction of costs attributable to a qualifying shareholding. These costs are set off against any tax-exempt dividends or cap ital gains received during the taxable year; any excess may then be set off against other taxable income. - The deduction of losses resulting from the distribution of the profits of a subsidiary are generally deductible in France, Germany, Italy and Luxembourg. - In the United Kingdom and Ireland capital losses are only deductible against capital gains. - Belgium and Spain have amended their legislation as a result of the Directive so that such losses are no longer deductible. - Under the Danish participation exemption system capital losses are only allowed as a deduction if the shareholding has been held for less than three years at the time of dis posal.

52 ® VOLUME 32 - european taxation 1992 No. 4/5 EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES: Implementation of the Parent-Subsidiary Directive in the Member States INTRODUCTION By Rijkele Betten* The Council Directive on the common system of taxation of parent companies and subsidiaries of different Member States was adopted on 23 July 1990.' The main purpose of the Parent-Subsidiary Directive is to enable the grouping of companies within the Common Market. This is neces sary in order to stimulate the development of relations within the Common Market, and it was not designed to be a protectionist measure. As long as the more developed Member States have tax incentives for inbound (domestic) incentives as opposed to tax disadvantages for outbound investments, the other Member States do not have a fair chance to develop. Such developments are desirable for a variety of reasons; for example, they would improve human welfare, increase political and social stability, result in a uniform application and protection of human rights, improve efforts to protect the environment, and avoid over-concentration (of industry, population) in cer tain Member States. All EC Member States were to enact before 1 January 1992 the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary to bring them into compliance with the Parent- Subsidiary Directive (Article 8(1)). 2 Germany, Portugal and Greece were granted additional time in certain respects (Article 5(2), (3) and (4)), but they must still implement the other provisions by 1 January 1992. TREATMENT OF THE PARENT Article 4 of the Directive concerns the taxation of the par ent. In principle Member States are now obliged to exempt from tax profit distributions at the level of the parent. The exemption may be implemented by granting either an exemption or a credit. The taxation of the shareholders owning the parent is not covered by the Directive. An important purpose of the Directive is to bring the taxa tion of "intra-EC groupings" in line with the taxation of groupings within each EC Member State. In principle that leaves roem for 12 different systems, and a Member State can fulfil its obligations as long as it exempts profit distri butions of subsidiaries and applies the rules for domestic groupings to intra-EC groupings (to the extent required by the Directive). Thus uniformity in, or harmonization of, the taxation of groupings is by no means a necessary con sequence of the Directive. Instead, each Member State can take into account its own particular circumstances. The most important factors affecting the implementation seem to be the revenue position of the government and the taxa tion of resident groupings of companies. PROFIT DISTRIBUTIONS Article 5 of the Directive provides that no withholding tax may be levied on outgoing "intra-EC profit distributions". This abolition of withholding tax means a revenue loss for all Member States that levy such withholding taxes. It is therefore not surprising that the Member States tend to implement this part of the Directive restrictively. In practice the most burdensome condition that Member States may impose relates to the holding period. By requir ing a holding period of two years, a Member State may postpone the revenue loss for these two years. In some cases, lower dividend withholding taxes applied to hold ings of less than 25 percent (e.g. German-Netherlands quintet-situation). If, in order to qualify for the exemption in the Directive, the shareholding has to be increased to 25 percent, the two-year holding period has no economic rel evance but serves as a tool for the Government to save revenues in the short-run. Surprisingly, there is not much statistical data on the mag nitude of the dividend streams between the Member States; therefore, the revenue consequences of the Direc tive are very difficult to quantify. EC LAW The application of direct EC law is a new phenomenon for tax practitioners or tax advisers as well as for tax adminis trators. The financial interest accompanying this area of taxation will be a great stimulus for the fast development of EC direct tax law. Both taxpayers and governments must protect their interests, and that is only possible by a proper understanding and application of EC law. EC law has been important for a much longer period of time in connection with other (non-tax) areas of the law, e.g. company law, VAT, social security, competition, non discrimination, etc. Still, each Member State has its own legal system in these areas, and the application of the direct tax profession is by no means likely to be harmo nized in the nearby future. To the contrary, more "types" of law are becoming relevant, and application of tax law to routine cases requires a good understanding of EC law on the part of the legislature, taxpayer and tax administrator. * Research Staff Member, International Bureau of Fiscal Documentation. 1.
